description: With a secondary frequentative suffix -er, ultimately pointing to Proto-Germanic *hankōną, an iterative to *hanhaną (“to hang”). Related to Dutch hunkeren (“to crave”), which continues the zero-grade iterative.

verbs.description: hanker (third-person singular simple present hankers, present participle hankering, simple past and past participle hankered)

examples: If you hanker for chocolate, you'll like this fudge recipe.
